text: While i'm in the Ubuntu, I am unable to screenshot anything. Did I do something wrong or do I need to set that up somehow?

elements.text: While i'm in the Ubuntu, I am unable to screenshot anything. Did I do something wrong or do I need to set that up somehow?

text: Try using the snipping tool. When using the virtual machine, your keyboard may not register in the host machine. Link to similar question: <https://is-1003-spring-2023.slack.com/archives/C04JVFGJLQ2/p1676673006606109>

elements.text: Try using the snipping tool. When using the virtual machine, your keyboard may not register in the host machine. Link to similar question:
Is anyone else having trouble trying to screenshot their full screen Linux machine? I am on Windows 11 and
can’t
seem to screenshot unless i am clicked off of the virtual machine.

attachments.fallback: [February 17th, 2023 2:30 PM] kyle.kotara2: Is anyone else having trouble trying to screenshot their full screen Linux machine? I am on Windows 11 and can’t seem to screenshot unless i am clicked off of the virtual machine.
attachments.text: Is anyone else having trouble trying to screenshot their full screen Linux machine? I am on Windows 11 and can’t seem to screenshot unless i am clicked off of the virtual machine.

text: You can screenshot from your host machine using the Windows Snipping Tool (and you do not need to save the screenshot; you can just paste it into your document!).

elements.text: You can screenshot from your host machine using the Windows Snipping Tool (and you do not need to save the screenshot; you can just paste it into your document!).

text: Yes, snipping tool is what I meant. :) So, as long as I am in my host and I can see the screen on my guest machine, am I understanding that correctly?

elements.text: Yes, snipping tool is what I meant. :) So, as long as I am in my host and I can see the screen on my guest machine, am I understanding that correctly?

Hi all: On step #7 (Guest Additions), you may receive a message like the screenshot below.
These instructions

(under the Guest Additions section) contain the commands needed to install these modules. They are different than my alternative instructions in the lab file (which should work too, but if they don't...).

They are different than my alternative instructions in the lab file (which should work too, but if they don't...).

text: Great! And that's okay! Instructions given online or by me, frankly, are for a given point in time. They are "more like guidelines" (Barbossa from Pirates). If you do your lab after the time of publication, you will likely encounter a different environment (as is the case with my instructions).

text: In Step 8 under point 4, it says that the command ll is a shortcut for ls -l. But when I type ll and ls -l in the terminal, I get different results. However, ll seems to have the same results as the ls -al command. Is ll a shortcut for ls -al, or am I missing something?

elements.text: In Step 8 under point 4, it says that the command ll is a shortcut for ls -l. But when I type ll and ls -l in the terminal, I get different results. However, ll seems to have the same results as the ls -al command. Is ll a shortcut for ls -al, or am I missing something?

text: Excellent catch, Sara! In some Linux flavors, it may be "aliased" to ls -al.

elements.text: Excellent catch, Sara! In some Linux flavors, it may be "aliased" to ls -al.

text: Thank you!

elements.text: Thank you!

text: How do I fix the issue that it says This program must be run with administrator privileges. Aborting?

elements.text: How do I fix the issue that it says This program must be run with administrator privileges. Aborting?

text: Hi David: To run a program with administrative privileges, you can insert the word "sudo" before your command.

elements.text: Hi David: To run a program with administrative privileges, you can insert the word "sudo" before your command.

text: Hey everyone I have a question! While setting up the VM I got this prompt of "pre-allocate" rather than "dynamically allocate." I am using a galaxy book 12 windows computer so that is probably why it's different. Do I check this box off or no? Thank you!!

elements.text: Hey everyone I have a question! While setting up the VM I got this prompt of "pre-allocate" rather than "dynamically allocate." I am using a galaxy book 12 windows computer so that is probably why it's different. Do I check this box off or no? Thank you!!

text: Never mind I figured it out!! I selected the "help" option and just scrolled down until I found the area I was stuck on and it was there!!
